title: RoboEarth: Connecting robots world-wide

author: Heico Sandee, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Eindhoven University of Technology

segmentation: Thank you very much.

It's my pleasure as a coordinator to present you the Roberth project, which is a collaboration between six parties, of which five or technical universities and universities of Eindhoven, Zaragoza, Stuttgart, Moonshae theory and the company Phillips.
Um?

As you all know and from your own experience, probably when dealing with robots, and especially as we're dealing with domestic service robots, it's use huge challenge for these researches to deal with the instructions in the environment where the robots need to operate in.

If you look at a lot of practices then one famous way of dealing with this challenge is to try to generalize all the tasks that are open need to do, and also the objects that it needs in order to do these tasks.
And then going to the execution after.

Well, some generalized concept, you often run into the fact that this robot has still to deal with the specific ality, the special details of this certain task, and this often results in, for instance, the first 10 trials going wrong.
For instance, when you try to grab a new Cup and the first night go wrong, you know in a new environment, so it's difficult.
Or for instance, it results in a nice demonstrated movie of robots doing something.
But then on the bottom right corner you see this.
Always this timestamp is really annoying.
So the fishing off the Robo Earth project is that an order for robots to really become effective and efficient?

These robots need to, well, first of all, learn to a depth and you environments, but more importantly, they need to share this information with other robots in order for other robots to use this information to perform the same task or similar tasks more effectively and more efficiently.
Um, this is actually a similar as how.
Human beings are doing this.
For instance, if you have just learned how to bake new cake, then nowadays we like to put it, for instance on the Internet, and we do this using a very common language, very informal instructions.
We put it on the web enabling other people to read this and to make the same cake in a similar way using common sense to interpret the data and to execute the same recipe.

If he tried to do this with robots, we do need to formalize things, because these Roble need to communicate with each other and form away, and this is still quite difficult because we don't want to restrict ourselves to a certain specific set of task or as per certain specific set of objects.
So questions appeared.
Then like what are we going to export?
What kind of data do we need to share and how are we going to represent this information?
And on the other side, the user may ask how should I ever find the right information that I need in order to execute a certain task?
Or how do I execute this task?
So in Roberth we're trying working hard on.
Answering these questions.
Francis for how to represent the data.
We're working on a formal language to represent the data using also a big knowledge base.
For the question how to export data or you're working on recipe extraction, which pretty much related to previous talk, how to find the data in the database?
Working on semantic web like services or how to execute it working on capability matching code generation.
So actually how to develop a real code from the plan that is only on the data shared from both from another robot.
We can grounding and transformation of representations just to name a few.

Looking at what we're doing in the project.

Let me try to point the plan based controller.
This is beer has been developed in Cram by our partner in Munich.
Graham is a plan based controller language, so it's actually implementing the plans that are shared on the between robots.
Actually, these plans are pretty much the same as in the previous talk were explained as action schemas.
If I remember correctly.
This plan makes controller works together with with the knowledge base which is implemented in norup.
As input from the player for a plan based controller, there is a fee slam system and a system that does the object recognition actually.
Francis for this object recognition.
It is also very valuable to use data from other robots.
So if a robot has learned how to detect an object, for instance, he has model of the object.
You can share this model with the other robots such that the other robot can use it as well.
So all these models, all these all this knowledge is shared using one using a database which is on this upper left corner which we call the robot database.
Which is in the Internet.
It's on the cloud based database.
And next thing that is inputs for the four year plan based controller are articulation models.
So information on how the robots shoot.
For instance, open the door or things like that.
So that's also input for the plan based controller and then at the end everything is mapped onto the robot and the robot executes the complete plan.
But of course, not every robot can execute the plan that another robot has generated, because robots might be very much different.
So we need to sort of match the capabilities that the robot has to the requirements of the certain plan.
For this we we are specifying the capabilities of the robot in a semantic robot description language.
This allows us to to actually do this matching between the plans that we have from the database on Roberth database and the task that we need to execute.
I want this match is when the tasks that we need to execute metrics a plan which is on the database we actually download this plan to the robot and start executing.
But next to this plan, there's more that needs to be downloaded.
There's all kinds of information that is valuable for the plan in order to execute, for instance, Maps of the environments or models of the object.
Like I said before.
But there might be different Maps so.
This is currently in the database we have.
This is just an example set of Maps that we have a specific room so we have a semantic map.
We have a 2D map, also 3D map created by fee slam system.
So we have all these different kinds of Maps and these of course need to be located on the database.
After this, every map.
A couple 2 and that's on our file which specifies the location of the map, so it actually specifies simply like.
This is a map from a room in a certain building, which is in a certain street that is certain in a certain city, allowing us to do locate right map.
But still you may download the map, which is not corresponding to the way you would like to use the map with a specific robot.
So for instance, if you have robots, well if you have.
Like here in the in the left hand corner this map is generated by by by using a camera just a handheld Kinect going through the room, generating a 3D map.
But this robot in the middle shown is used to navigate using his laser scanner.
So it needs actually a mapa Tooting map at a certain height.
The height of the laser scan.
So one of the things which is here a simple example, though a services that we run on a database in order to translate the information we have on the database to the information that the robot needs.

So for instance, for this example we can transform this database as a service running transfer or transform the 3D map that we have on the database to a 2D map for the laser Range Finder at a specific height.
In order for that robot to use this information.
And this is just one of the examples of services that can run on such a database.

For instance to detect the.
The ball the plan which is which is an ASCII file, so not very high demanding.
But if you really would use a database for real time, each process is like you need an update of every second.
Then you really need to think of how to how to do this, that's true.
So if you want my opinion with what's the best way of doing this is combining.

A local part of the database at your robot together with the global part, which is in the cloud and you want to transfer as much as knowledge as possible already to your local database in order to use this with with the real time manner so the database is not really designed at this moment to to do coral collaborative actions with two robots functioning at the same time in the same room, for instance, which would require a real time demands there.
